Euphrates River valley as well as intercepting the Iraqi troops fleeing along the Hamal dike road. This was definitely the most deeply significant tactical operation of the ground war. It proclaimed that, from this point, helicopters were perfectly capable of conducting large-scale operations independently. When the throngs of Iraqi soldiers ran from the fortifications destroyed by the helicopters and knelt to beg to surrender, they were in turn herded into a group by the helicopters just like a cattle drive, and the view that “only the infantry can ultimately resolve a battle” has now been radically shaken by these American “flying cowboys.” Originally, the initial intent of the leapfrog operation by the helicopters was just to provide support for the armored units that were to handle the main offensive, but the unexpected success of the helicopter units caused the plan to fall far behind the developments in the battle situation. Because of this, Schwarzkopf had to order the VII Corps to attack 15 hours ahead of time, and although under the command of General Franks the speed of the advance of the VII Corps through the desert was far faster than that of Gudarian, who became famous for launching tank blitzkriegs, he did not win the good “blitzkrieg” reputation, but actually was rebuked for “moving forward slowly, one step at a time, like an old lady.” Following the war, General Franks refuted the criticism that came from the allied headquarters in Riyadh, based on the reason that the Iraqi military still had fighting capabilities.
In reality, neither the critics nor those who refuted them had grasped the essence of the problem. The reason that the mobility of the tanks under General Franks’ command was criticized was precisely because of the comparison with the helicopters. To this day, there has still been no example of combat which has demonstrated that any kind of tanks can keep up with the combat pace of helicopters. Actually, this did not just involve mobility. As the former “kings of land warfare,” the tanks are being challenged by the helicopters on all fronts. Compared to the tanks, which have to constantly labor to overcome the coefficient of friction of the earth’s surface, the helicopters’ battlespace is at treetop level, so they are totally unaffected by any surface obstacles and their excellent mobility is sufficient to cancel out the flaw of not having heavy armor. Similarly, as mobile weapons platforms, their firepower is by no means inferior to that of the tanks, and this represents the greatest crisis encountered by tanks since they ascended the stage of warfare. What is even tougher for the tanks is the energy required to organize a sizable tank group assault (transporting a given number of tanks to a staging area alone is a massive headache) and the risks one runs (when tanks are massed, they are extremely vulnerable to preemptive strikes by the enemy), so they really have no advantages to speak of when compared to helicopters, which are good at dispersed deployment and concentrated strikes, and which can be massed to engage in conventional warfare or dispersed to fight guerrilla warfare. In fact, tanks and helicopters are natural enemies, but the former is far from a match for the latter, and even the outmoded AH-1 “Cobra” helicopters, not to mention the AH-64 “tank-killer” helicopters, destroyed upwards of 100 tanks during the Gulf War while sustaining no casualties at all of their own. Faced with the powerful strike capabilities of the helicopters, who can still maintain that “the best weapon to deal with tanks are tanks?” We can now say that helicopters are the true tank terminators. This new star, which rose gradually over the waves of the Gulf, is in the process of achieving its own coronation through the illustrious battle achievements during the Gulf War, and there is no doubt that it is just a question of time before it drives the tank from the battlefield. It may not take very long before “winning a land battle from the air” is no longer an overdramatized slogan, and more and more ground force commanders are reaching a consensus on this point. Furthermore, the new concepts of a “flying army” and “flying ground warfare” in which the helicopter is the main battle weapon may become standard military jargon and appear in every military dictionary.

Leaving aside the point that as commander in chief of the three services Bush certainly knew the time the attack was to begin, when viewed simply in terms of the CNN television broadcasts, the whole world was the same as the U.S. president in that they saw at the same time the soul-stirring start of the war. In the information-sharing age, a president doesn’t really have much more in the way of special privileges than an ordinary citizen. This is where modern warfare differs from any wars of the past, with realtime or near real-time reports turning warfare into a new program that ordinary people can monitor directly via the media, and thus the media has become an immediate and integral part of warfare, and no longer merely provides information coming from the battlefield. Unlike a direct broadcast of a World Cup soccer match, everything that people saw, other than that which was first limited by the subjective perspective of the television reporters (the 1,300 reporters sent to the front lines were all aware of the “Revised Regulations Regarding Gulf War News Reports” that had just been issued by the Pentagon, so each person in his own mind exercised restraint about what could and could not be reported), also had to go through the security reviews at the joint news offices set up in Dhahran and Riyadh. Perhaps U.S. military circles and the media had both learned the lesson during the Vietnam War when the discord between the two was so great, but this time the news agencies and the military got along very well. There is one figure that perhaps can illustrate this issue very well. Of the more than 1,300 news items released throughout the entire period of the war, only five were sent to Washington for review, and of these four received approval within several hours, while the remaining item was canceled by the press unit itself. With the concerted assistance of the news reporters, the battlefield commanders successfully influenced the eyes and ears of the entire world, getting people to see everything that the military wanted them to see, while no one was able to see anything that they did not want people to know. The U.S. press uniformly abandoned its vaunted neutrality, enthusiastically joining the anti-Iraq camp and coordinating with the U.S. military just like an outstanding two-man comic act, quite tacitly and energetically arriving at the same script for the war, with the force of the media and that of the allied army forming a joint force regarding the attack on Iraq. Not long after Iraq invaded Kuwait, reports quickly appeared in the various media that a massive U.S. force was streaming into Saudi Arabia, causing the Iraqi military on the Kuwait-Saudi Arabia border to flinch and quietly creating the necessary momentum for a “hobbling” operation. The day before the start of “Desert Storm,” the Western media again trumpeted the news of a U.S. carrier fleet passing through the Suez Canal, which served to confuse Saddam and have him believe that, with disaster looming, the U.S. forces had still not completed their deployment. Similarly, without the support of the embellishment by the media, none of the so-called high-tech weapons sent to be used in the Gulf War would have been as awesome as people believed. In the upwards of 98 press conferences held throughout the entire course of the war, people saw images of how the precision-guided missiles could penetrate the air vents in a building and explode, of “Patriots” intercepting “Scuds,” and numerous other shots that left a profound impression. All these things represented an intense visual shock to the entire world, including the Iraqis, and it was from this that the myth about the unusual powers of the U.S.-made weapons was born, and it was here that the belief was formed that “Iraq would inevitably lose, and the U.S. was bound to win.” Obviously, the media helped the Americans enormously. We might as well say that, intentionally or otherwise, the U.S. military and the Western media joined hands to form a noose to hang Saddam’s Iraq from the gallows. In the “Operational Outline” that was revised after the war, the Americans took pains to suggest that “the force of the media reports was able to have a dramatic effect on the strategic direction and the scope of the military operations,” while the newly drafted field manual FM10O-6 (Information Operations) goes even farther in using the example of the media war during the Gulf War. It would appear that, in all future wars, in addition to the basic method of military strikes, the force of the media will increasingly be another player in the war and will play a role comparable to that of military strikes in promoting the course of the war. Unlike battlefield propaganda, which has an excessively subjective tinge and is easily rejected by an opponent or neutral individuals, because it is cleverly cloaked as objective reporting the media has a quiet impact that is hard to gauge. In the Gulf, in the same manner that the U.S.-led allied forces deprived Iraq of its right to speak militarily, the powerful Western media deprived it politically of its right to speak, to defend itself, and even of its right to sympathy and support, and compared to the weak voice of Iraqi propaganda, which portrayed Bush as the “great Satan” who was wicked beyond redemption, the image of Saddam as a war-crazed aggressor was played up in a much more convincing fashion. It was precisely the lopsided media force together with the lopsided military force that dealt a vicious one-two blow to Iraq on the battlefield and morally, and this sealed Saddam’s defeat. However, the effects of the media have always been a two-edged sword. This means that, while it is directed at the enemy, at the same time on another front it can similarly be a sharp sword directed at oneself. Based on information that was disclosed following the war, the reason that the ground war abruptly came to a halt after 100 hours was actually because Bush, influenced by a hasty assessment of the course of the war that was issued on television by a battlefield news-release officer, later came to a similarly hasty decision of his own, “dramatically shortening the time from strategic decision-making to concluding the war.” As a result, Saddam, whose days were numbered, escaped certain death, and it also left a string of “desert thunder” operations, which were ultimately duds, for Clinton, who came to power later. The impact of the media on warfare is becoming increasingly widespread and increasingly direct, to the point where even major decisions by the president of a superpower such as this one involving the cessation of hostilities are to a very great extent rooted in the reaction to a single television program. From this, one can perceive a bit of the significance that the media carries in social life today. One can say entirely without exaggeration that an uncrowned king has now become the major force to win any battle. After “Desert Storm” swept over the Gulf, no longer would it be possible to rely on military force alone without the involvement of the media to achieve victory in a war.

LES ASPIN THE GULF WAR has been the United States military’s biggest war catch in the past few decades. When the war had just ended, the American military, members of Congress, and various civic organizations began to carry out a detailed examination of this catch from different points of view. From each of the reports submitted by them and each of the steps subsequently taken by the American military, the tremendous achievements of this examination can be seen. These achievements, moreover, are all extremely valuable to armies and military personnel throughout the world, and there must be no delay in looking at them. Because the nationalistic instincts of the Americans I especially admire are particularly prominent in the longstanding sectarianism that exists among the military services, theoretical blind spots and thought errors are bound to occur in the research, to the extent that a grand warfare investigation has been turned into a blind person trying to size up an elephant. This is a topic that requires our clear reexamination and should not be treated as an excuse to deny its value. But what is it, after all, that Americans want to feel on this big beast? Let’s first take a look at it. HAND EXTENDED UNDER THE MILITARY FENCE (EACH ARMED SERVICE VIEWS WAR DIFFERENTLY) The fence erected between the U.S. Army and the Navy since the time of the Civil War not only could not be eliminated after the birth of the U.S. Air Force, it instead became the fence separating the three branches of the military. It became the historical chronic disease giving headaches to the president and the Pentagon. Even though there was an effective “reorganization method” during the Gulf War, it was not so much a clever way for getting to the root of the problem as it was an expedient measure for bringing about a temporary solution in light of this invisible obstacle. As soon as things had settled down and all the troops had returned home, the doors were closed as before and everyone went their own way. Nevertheless, the high-ranking officers at the head of each of the three military branches certainly not a mediocre generation of stupidly unchanging leaders. The course and outcome expected from the Gulf War at the time when it shocked the whole world also deeply shook these “Desert Storm” policymakers. The dumbfounded feelings of having lost an adversary that came as a result of the dissolution of the Soviet Union along with the renewed motivation to establish the United States at the forefront of the new world order made these leaders clearly realize the urgency with which they must reform the armed forces even though they still had no intention of abandoning their prejudices. In view of each of the successive military combat regulations in the 1990s, its starting points have without exception been established on the basis of the many fresh experiences and lessons gained in the Gulf War. Just as “in the eyes of a thousand people, there are a thousand views,” what unfolded in the eyes of the three branches of the U.S. military were three different Gulf Wars. In this war, which not only was the last war of old times, but also the inaugural war of modern times, each of the three branches stuck to its own arguments and made every effort to find the evidence most advantageous to its respective branch, hardly realizing that the hand outstretched from behind the military wall could not possibly make heads or tails of such a big elephant as the Gulf War. section: Post-Gulf War U.S. Military Transformation and Inter-Service Rivalry
text: Though the U.S. Army performed adequately in Desert Storm, its showing was not considered outstanding, especially compared to the Air Force's bombing campaign. General Sullivan, recognizing the potential for stagnation after the Cold War, initiated plans for a "21st Century Army," focusing on digitization and information warfare. This initiative, while ostensibly aimed at modernization, also served to secure a larger share of the shrinking military budget. His successor, General Reimer, continued this strategy, using the "digitized force" as a justification for increased funding.  However, the rapid pace of technological change made it difficult to finalize designs and establish a stable force. The dependence on a single technology also raised concerns about creating an "electronic Maginot Line."  The Air Force, emboldened by its success in the Gulf War, sought to assert its dominance within the armed forces. Generals McPeak and Fogleman aimed to capitalize on their proven air power capabilities, reorganizing their forces and establishing an expeditionary force capable of rapid deployment.  They also prioritized electronic and information warfare, establishing a dedicated center. However, inter-service rivalry, particularly with the Army over operational command, hampered the effective sharing of lessons learned from the Gulf War.  The Navy, having played a minimal role in Desert Storm, underwent a significant strategic shift.  Moving away from Mahan's doctrine of commanding the seas, the Navy embraced a new focus on supporting coastal and land-based operations, as outlined in the white paper "From Sea to Land."  This transformation, further emphasized in subsequent documents, aimed to secure the Navy's relevance and budgetary share.  Admiral Boorda and his successor, Admiral Johnson, championed this new direction, arguing that the Navy's unique global reach made it the ideal core of a joint combat force.  This strategy proved successful, with the Navy experiencing minimal budget cuts compared to other branches.

Large-scale use of costly weapons to reduce casualties without counting costs—this kind of warfare, waged by the wealthy, is a game the American military excels at. “Desert Storm” showcased American extravagance, becoming an addiction.  Expensive aircraft conducted indiscriminate bombings, destroying targets with costly missiles and precision-guided bombs. Even if aware of the unnecessary expense of this \$61 billion banquet, their extravagance was unchecked. An American bomber, more costly than many targets, raises suspicions.  For 161 days, personnel and materials were transported, including unnecessary items like sun hats and rotting fruit. This extravagant logistical operation was deemed “historically unheard of.”  Only Americans would consider this necessary to win a war. The Pentagon, remolded by McNamara’s commercial spirit, focuses on the costs of luxury warfare. Even the House Armed Services Committee remained silent on the astonishing expenditures.  High-technology weaponry received high praise, with Secretary of Defense Cheney boasting of a generational lead in weapons technology. This wasn't just pride in achieving objectives; it reflects a national unwillingness to pay the price of life, always vying for victory at all costs. High-technology weaponry satisfies this extravagant hope.  During the Gulf War, casualty numbers were remarkably low.  Since Vietnam, both the military and society have become sensitive, almost morbid, about casualties. Reducing casualties and achieving war objectives are equally weighted. American soldiers have become precious commodities.  Opponents have learned that if they cannot defeat the force, they should target the soldiers. The Congressional Report confirms, “reducing casualties is the highest objective.” The pursuit of zero casualties motivates American-style extravagant warfare.  The unchecked use of advanced weaponry and tactics prioritizes minimizing casualties, even if it means using disproportionate force.  This warfare is like killing a chicken with a bull knife. High-technology, high-investment, and high-expenditure reduce the need for sophisticated strategy and skill. This war became a showcase of high-tech weaponry, spreading American-style extravagance globally.  As the world’s leading arms dealers, Americans are overjoyed. This high-tech, dull, and expensive war, like a Hollywood movie with a simple plot and complex special effects, left many believing this is how modern warfare is fought, creating a yearning for high-technology weapons. Americans, skilled in machinery and infatuated with luxuries, have a penchant for turning technology into luxury, including weapons.  This infatuation leads to blind faith in technology, believing it holds the key to victory. They constantly strive to maintain their technological lead, producing newer, more complex weapons.  This prioritization of weaponry over strategy and courage makes them view war as a technological race rather than a test of morale and wisdom.  Their self-confidence makes them forget that war is not a fixed race course but a dynamic field with unpredictable factors. While they benefited from the Gulf War’s technological victory, they remain resolute in maintaining their technological edge, despite funding difficulties.  The list of extravagant weapons will grow, but the casualty count in future wars may not remain zero.

The U.S. Army has grappled with the question of its 21st-century needs. The Gulf War highlighted the contrast between the Army's mediocre performance and the impact of high-technology weapons. This spurred the need for reform, with resistance coming not from the upper echelon but from newly promoted division commanders.  The “brigade faction,” however, believed the Army troops needed an overhaul, advocating for programs like “crack troops,” “model troops,” and “primary brigade.”  General Sullivan, despite supporting these new ideas, couldn't convince the majority of generals. After his departure, a compromise led to the creation of a new experimental brigade based on the Fourth Mechanized Unit. The “divisional faction” prevailed. The “brigade faction” persisted, arguing against a cumbersome military force, advocating for smaller, more agile combat troops.  Amidst this debate, Lieutenant Colonel Maigeleige proposed abandoning both division and brigade systems in favor of 5,000-man battle groups. This flexible, mission-oriented approach resonated, with General Reimer requiring all generals to read Maigeleige’s book. The concept of a “group” wasn't new, but previous attempts were unsuccessful.  Maigeleige argued that modern weaponry empowers smaller forces, and the C4I system enables united action, making traditional divisional or brigade systems obsolete.  While technological advancement doesn’t automatically translate to advanced military thought, Maigeleige’s “group” concept challenged established structures, representing a new wave of thinking in U.S. Army reform.  Unlike the Army, the Air Force and Navy, lacking entrenched traditions, adapted more readily.

section: Part 1: Expeditionary Forces and Institutional Reforms
text: The U.S. Air Force rapidly transitioned away from the divisional system, converting combat flight wings into integrated wings. Driven by the strategic objective of "global arrival, global power," they tested the "Air Force Expeditionary Force" concept. This involved deploying a nimble force of 1,175 personnel and 34 aircraft within 48 hours, capable of maintaining air combat throughout a conflict.  Three such forces were established and deployed in operations like "Southern Watch" and "Desert Thunder." The Navy, guided by the "Forward Position … From Sea to Land" strategy, pursued a similar approach. Through exercises like "Ocean Risk," "Double Assault," and "Silent Killer," and real-world operations such as "Southern Watch" and "Hope Renewal," the Navy refined its expeditionary force concept. This force, comprising a battleship group, an amphibious guard force, and Marine Corps task forces, aimed to rapidly control seas and engage in coastal combat.  These reforms impacted weapons development, tactics, and even national strategy. The small, flexible expeditionary forces, suitable for both combat and non-combat tasks, became a favored tool for the U.S. government, leading to an increased reliance on force in international affairs.

section: Part 2: From Joint Campaigns to Total Dimensional War
text: While American military technology leads, its theory sometimes lags.  The Gulf War highlighted the need to align military thinking with technological advancements. The U.S. military engaged in "thought exchange transfusion," focusing on "joint campaign" and "total dimensional warfare" concepts.  The "joint campaign" concept, originating from the "United States Armed Forces Joint Operations" regulations, emphasized centralized command, equality of armed forces, complete unification, and total depth in battle.  This aimed to improve inter-service cooperation and unified operations. However, internal resistance persisted, with branches prioritizing their core functions and seeking clearly defined roles and authorities.  Despite Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Shalikashvili's efforts, skepticism remained, particularly within the Marine Corps and Air Force, who valued service distinctiveness and flexibility. The "joint campaign" concept, while valuable in promoting interoperability, remained limited by its focus on armed forces rather than a broader understanding of conflict.  The 1993 U.S. Army publication "The Essentials of War" introduced the concept of "non-combat military operations," hinting at total positional warfare and "total dimensional warfare." This concept emphasized total depth, height, frontage, time, frequency, and multiple methods.  However, this revolutionary idea faced internal opposition, with some arguing against differentiating between combat and non-combat operations. This resistance ultimately led to the discontinuation of this line of thinking within the Army.

The Army Training and Doctrine Headquarters, under General Hartzog and General Holder, along with the editorial group for the 1998 publication of *The Essentials of War*, implemented a significant amendment. This amendment established “a single principle covering all types of the Army’s military operations.”  They moved away from distinguishing between non-combat and general military operations, instead classifying battle operations into four types: attack, defense, stabilization, and support.  Traditional non-combat operations like rescue, protection, and reassembly were re-categorized. This aimed to streamline combat principles and discard the concept of “total dimensional warfare.”

While seemingly a simplification, this revision was arguably flawed. Eliminating the confusing “non-combat military operations” concept also discarded valuable associated insights.  This mirrors a common pattern of progress followed by regression.  However, criticizing the U.S. Army's approach doesn't invalidate critiques of “total dimensional warfare.”  The theory has flaws in both denotation and connotation.  While “total dimensional war” broadens the understanding of battle beyond previous theories, it remains confined within the “military” category.

The concept of “non-military combat operations” surpasses military combat operations, encompassing realms beyond the scope of American military thinking. This is a fertile ground for future strategists to explore. Consequently, “total dimensional warfare” falls short of its implied comprehensiveness. The U.S. Army's definition lacks clarity on the number of dimensions involved and their interrelationships.  Without a clear understanding of the dimensions, the relationships between them—a concept with significant potential—cannot be fully developed.

Practically, no war can encompass all dimensions, including time and non-physical elements.  Every war has specific focuses and operates within limited dimensions. section: Cocktail in the Great Master's Cup
text: COCKTAIL IN THE GREAT MASTER’S CUP King Wu of the Zhou Dynasty three thousand years ago and Alexander the Great over two thousand years ago definitely would not have known what a cocktail was, and yet they were both masters of mixing “cocktails” on the battlefield. This is because, like mixing a cocktail, they were adept at ingeniously combining two or more battlefield factors together, throwing them into battle, and gaining victories. 1+1 is the most elementary and also the most ancient combination method. Long spears and round shields can prepare a soldier for both attack and defense and give a basis for advancing and retreating; two people comprise a unit, wherein “soldiers with long weapons are used for defense and those with short weapons are used for holding positions,” a pair of soldiers coordinate with each other, and then form the smallest tactical unit.11 The knight Don Quixote and his attendant Sancho signify that the separation of work of the general and the light soldier had already been formed, and thus the team could set off on a long journey to dispel evil for the imaginary princess. Such a simple combination embodies the profound theory of infinite changes on the battlefield. From cold weapons to hot weapons and then on to nuclear weapons and up to the combination of the so- called high technology weapons of today, the musical instrument in the victorious magical hand has always accompanied the entire history of warfare secretly influencing the outcome of each war. King Wu attacked Zhuo with 300 military vehicles, 3,000 brave warriors, and 45,000 armored soldiers, which was far less than the several hundred thousand foot soldiers of King Zhuo of the Shang Dynasty. However, this small army composed of both vehicles and soldiers became the cornerstone of the Zhou kingdom, because the proper combination greatly strengthened the combat strength in the wilderness war and became the evidence of the earliest combination war which we were able to find 3,120 years later. Given that this was the case in the East, the West was no exception. The reason why Alexander was able to defeat a large army during one decisive battle at Abeila was because he made adaptations just before going into battle, wherein a linear pushing square matrix changed so that the opponent was taken by surprise. His method was very simple. The position of the cavalry shifted back and obliquely along the two flanks of the square matrix forming a “hollow large square matrix,” so that the flexibility of the cavalry and the stability of the foot soldiers achieved the ideal combination in a unique battle array wherein each developed their individual strengths most incisively. The result was naturally that Alexander, whose military force was at a comparative disadvantage, ultimately drank heartily the cup of victory.12 When perusing the military history of both East and West, we never find the expression “combination” in any of the descriptions related to methods of operation. However, all of the great masters of warfare throughout the ages seem to have instinctively known this principle well. The King of Sweden Gustav was the most highly praised military reformer at the beginning of the firearms period. All of the reforms that he carried out in terms of battle array and weapons deployment used the combination method. He very early realized that the falling behind of the lancers and arranging them together in battle array with the firearm soldiers allowed the former to be able to provide cover for the later between shootings. This developed the strengths of each to the greatest limits. He also often had mixed groupings of light cavalry, heavy cavalry and firearm soldiers who took turns initiating charges against the enemy’s skirmish line under the heavy smoke of artillery fire. This king was later called the “first great field artillery expert,” and he understood even better the functions and effects of artillery as the basis for engaging in battles. He took the light artillery as a combination of “regimental artillery” and infantry allowing the heavy artillery to independently form an army, and the seemingly separately deployed light and heavy artillery actually formed a perfectly integrated combination within the entire range of the battlefield. It can truly be said that the effects of the artillery were developed to the ultimate during that period.13 However, all of this occurred prior to the appearance of the expert of artillery technique, Napoleon. When compared with the short Corsican who pushed over 20,000 cannons on to the battlefield, the guns in the hands of Gustav can only be seen as “a small sorcerer in the presence of a great one.” During the period from 1793 to 1814, a total of 20 years, no one understood cannons as completely as did Napoleon. text: Regardless of whether the war was 3,000 years ago or at the end of the 20th century, it seems that all of the victories display one common phenomenon: the winner is the one who combined well. What is behind such terms is not only consideration of the need to deceive the enemy or the sound use of force. There must be some other reasons. In terms of instinct, all those famous generals who have won countless victories, or obscure people, have all realized the existence of something which perhaps should be called “rules of victory.” Those people have also got close to such rules tens of thousands of times. Nevertheless, to this day, no commander or philosopher has ever dared to say: I have found the rules. Not even the job of naming such rules has been completed. But, actually, the rules are hidden in the waves of military practice of mankind. It is proper to say that every classical victory has testified to the rules. However, each time, people either do not want to admit or do not dare to affirm their encounters with rules of victory, but, instead, often attribute the effects of the rules to the favor of some mysterious fate. Many “belated pronouncement” works on military history offer arguments which are difficult for people to grasp because the arguments describe the rules’ effects in an excessively mysterious manner. But rules of victory do exist. They are there. Like an invisible man, they accompany every war of mankind. Sage Pythagoras unexpectedly encountered a set of mysterious digits: 0.618. As a result, he found the rule of the golden section!  In the 2,500 years since then, this formula has been considered by formative artists as the golden rule of aesthetics. Almost all artistic works considered masterpieces have been close to or in accord with this formula in their basic aesthetic features. People had long marveled at the beauty of the Parthenon Temple of ancient Greece. With measurement and calculation, it was found that the relationship between its vertical lines and horizontal lines were entirely in accord with the 1:0.618 ratio.  Le Corbusier also established his theory of “basic design scale” on the basis of the rule of the golden section. Regrettably, this formula has never moved beyond the realm of artistic creation. It was not until 1953 that J. Kieffer, an American, discovered that seeking experiment points according to the rule of the golden section would make it possible to reach the optimal state the most quickly. His discovery was refined by Hua Luogeng into the “optimum seeking method,” or the 0.618 method. In fact, before this, people had repeatedly applied it to their own spheres of practice on the basis of their instincts, including the military sphere.  We can easily see examples of conforming to this rule everywhere in the military realm, ranging from the arc of the cavalry sword to the apex of the flying trajectory of a ballistic missile and from the optimum bomb-release altitude for an aircraft to the relationship between the length of the supply line and the turning point in a war. In the Yanlin battle, Duke Li of Jin used a portion of his middle army to attack the left army of the Chu force, used another portion to attack the middle army of the Chu force, and used the upper army, lower army, new army, and forces of the lords to attack the right army of the Chu force. The point of attack selected was exactly at the point of the golden section. In the Battle of Arbela, the Macedonians selected the juncture of the left flank and the center of the Persian force as the point of their attack; marvelously, the point was exactly the “golden point” for the entire front.

section: The Golden Section and Mongol Cavalry
text: For hundreds of years, people have found it difficult to understand why the Mongol cavalry of Gengis Khan were able to sweep across the Eurasian continent.  The rule of the golden section showed its miraculous power again: The battle formation of the Mongol cavalry was different from the Western traditional phalanx. In regard to their five-row formation, the ratio of heavy cavalry to light cavalry was 2:3, with 2 for armored heavy cavalry and 3 for fast and mobile light cavalry, that is, another example of the golden section!  It was natural for a force under the command of such a commander to have more striking power than the European forces that it confronted. Christian Europeans were late in coming to understand the application of this rule to other spheres. The Dutch general Maurice, who had been the first to transform the traditional phalanx by mixing similar numbers of musket-armed soldiers and pike-armed soldiers, failed to realize this point. It was King Gustavus of Sweden who adjusted this formation, thereby turning the Swedish army into an army with the strongest combat power in Europe of that time.  He had an additional 96 musket-armed soldiers in addition to the squadron composed of 216 pike-armed soldiers and 198 musket-armed soldiers. This change gave prominence to the use of firearms. We again saw the shining light of the rule of the golden section in the ratio of 198 plus 96 musket-armed soldiers to 216 pike-armed soldiers.

section: The Golden Section and Turning Points in War
text: Napoleon attacked Russia in June 1812. In September, after failing to eliminate effective Russian forces in the Borodino battle, he entered Moscow. A month later, the French forces withdrew from Moscow as it snowed heavily. There were three months of victorious advance and two months of declining. It seems that, in terms of the time sequence, the French emperor was standing on the line of the golden section when looking down at the city of Moscow through the burning fire. In another June 130 years later, Nazi Germany started the Barbarossa Plan against the Soviet Union. For as long as two years, German forces maintained their offensive momentum. It was in August 1943 that German forces turned into defense at the conclusion of the Castle action. The battle of Stalingrad, the turning point in the Soviet Patriotic War, happened exactly in the 17th month of the war, November 1942. This was the “golden point” in the time axis encompassing 26 months during which the German forces turned from booming to declining.  In the Gulf War, before the war, military experts estimated that the Republican Guard would lose combat effectiveness when losses reached 30 percent.  When the Desert Sword was taken out of its shield, Iraqi forces had lost 38 percent of their tanks, 32 percent of their armored vehicles, and 47 percent their artillery pieces.  The Desert Storm ground war ended 100 hours later.  Such instances scattered across history demonstrate a rule.

In Chinese grammar, there is a basic sentence structure: the side-principal structure.  This structure divides a sentence into two parts: the modifier and the center word. The modifier determines the tendency and features of the center word.  Relative to the center word, the modifier should be considered the center of a sentence or phrase. For instance, 'red apple'. Before being modified by 'red,' 'apple' only refers to a kind of fruit in general.  But 'red' gives this apple specificity.  In the side-principal structure, the 'side' element qualitatively determines the sentence.  The center word is the principal entity, with the modifier serving as the directing element.  The 'principal' element is the body, while the 'side' element is the soul.  The principal entity is subordinate to the directing element.  This side-principal relationship exists extensively beyond language.  The side-principal relationship exists in the movement and development of many things, and the 'side' element often plays the role as the directing element.  For instance, in a country, the people are the principal entity, while government is the directing element; in an armed force, soldiers and middle- and lower-level officers constitute the principal entity, while the command headquarters constitute the directing element; in a nuclear explosion, uranium or plutonium is the principal entity, while the means of bombarding them constitute the directing element; in a financial crisis, the victim countries are the principal entities, while financial speculators are the directing element. Without direction, the principal entity lacks coherence or purpose.

The side-principal structure involves a principal element and a side element, where the side element modifies the principal element. This asymmetrical structure, similar to the golden ratio (0.618:1), emphasizes the side element's importance.  Tian Ji's horse racing strategy exemplifies this, where losing one race strategically allows winning two, mirroring the 2:3 golden ratio.  This side-principal structure appears in military history. In the Changshao battle, the Lu army waited for the Qi army's momentum to wane before counterattacking, aligning with the golden ratio. Hannibal's tactics at Cannae similarly exploited the weakening Roman attack.  The German blitzkrieg during WWII, emphasizing tanks and targeting the Ardennes, showcased a side-element focus that revolutionized military thinking.  Yamamoto's Pearl Harbor attack, prioritizing aircraft carriers and targeting a seemingly unlikely location, further demonstrates this principle.

The side-principal rule, like the golden ratio, shouldn't be interpreted rigidly.  It represents adapting to dynamic battlefield conditions. This adaptability manifests in various ways: choosing dominant weapons (Schwarzkopf's Gulf War air campaign), tactics (Dönitz's U-boat tactics), points of attack (Nelson at Trafalgar), timing (Sadat's Yom Kippur War attack), force deployment (Schlieffen Plan), and stratagem (Fan Sui's advice during the Changping battle).  Increasingly, nations utilize non-military means alongside or instead of military ones, showcasing the side element's influence on the principal element (warfare).  This highlights the growing importance of the side-principal structure in future conflicts, where avoiding direct confrontation is crucial. This principle advocates for targeting the 'side' to achieve victory, emphasizing adaptability and avoiding brute force.

Within any system, a dominant element exists, ideally interacting harmoniously with other elements according to the golden ratio and side-principal rule.  The 'whole' represents the principal element, while the 'dominant element' acts as the directing side element.  Purpose dictates the dominant-subordinate relationship.  For instance, in bullfighting, horns (side) are subordinate to the bulls (principal), while in sword fighting, the edges (side) are subordinate to the swords (principal).  Changing the objective shifts the dominant element, creating a new side-principal relationship. Understanding this interplay is key to grasping the essence of these rules.  This understanding helps define key relationships in war: dominant weapons vs. all weapons, dominant means (like cyber warfare or economic pressure) vs. all means, dominant services vs. all services, dominant strategies vs. all strategies, and the dominant battlefield vs. all battlefields.

The dominant force and all the forces; the dominant direction and all the directions; and the dominant sphere and all the spheres. The relationship between the five dominant elements and all the elements in the five areas basically represent the side-principal relationship which exists in wars in a widespread manner. Take again the example of the Gulf War. In Operation Desert Storm, the dominant weapons used by the Allied Forces were stealth aircraft, cruise missiles, and precision bombs, with all other weapons playing a subordinate role. The dominant means was the 38 consecutive days of aerial bombardment, with other means playing a supplemental role. The dominant direction was to hit the Republican Guard as the target of focused attacks, with all other battlefield targets serving as secondary targets. The dominant sphere was the military sphere, with all other spheres providing comprehensive support in the forms of economic sanctions, diplomatic isolation, and media offensives. However, it is not our goal to just clarify such relationships. To people engaged in war, what is the most important is not to clarify things but to grasp and apply such relationships. As we know, all countries’ war resources are limited. Even such a powerful country as the United States still has to continually think about cost-effectiveness (the principal of the “least consumption of energy“) and how to fight wars in a more marvelous way and to produce more splendid war results. Therefore, it is very necessary for any country to use and allocate war resources in a sound and strategic manner. This will require finding a correct method, that is, the issue of how to consciously apply the side-principled rule. In fact, many countries have already subconsciously applied this rule before now. After the dissolution of the former Soviet Union, Russia’s military capability has declined continually. It has not only lost its superpower position of confronting the U.S. forces, but has even found it difficult to maintain national security now. Under such circumstances, the Russian high command has adjusted its future strategy in a timely fashion, despite being in a difficult position, making tactical, or even strategic, nuclear weapons the dominant weapons of first choice if a war is launched against Russia. On the basis of this decision, it has also adjusted the distribution of conventional weapons and nuclear weapons in an overall way. Contrary to Russia being the only superpower in the world, the U.S. Armed Forces have established as their new strategic objectives for the three services a “comprehensively superior” (army), a (navy) “moving from sea to land,” and a “globally engaged” (air force).” On that basis, digitized equipment, new types of amphibious attack vessels, and long-range stealth aircraft have been selected as a new generation of weapons, which appear to be replacing contemporary trump cards like tanks of the M-1 series, aircraft carriers, and F-16 fighters as the dominant weapons in the U.S. arsenal. As can be seen in the strategic adjustments made by Russia and the United States in regard to their respective dominant weapons, it seems that the practice of selecting the dominant weapons on the basis of the magnitude of destructive power is obsolete.

section: Dominant Weapons and the Changing Nature of Warfare
text: As far as the selection of the dominant weapons is concerned, the destructive power of weapons is but one of many items of technical performance of weapons. What is more important than technical performance is the basic consideration of the war aim, operational objectives, and security environment. Thus, the dominant weapons should be the most effective weapons for accomplishing the above mentioned goals. Furthermore, it is necessary to have them organically combined with other weapons, so as to formulate the dominant element of a complete arms system. Under conditions of modern technology, dominant weapons are no longer individual weapons, but “systems of weapons,” which are also components of larger systems. The emergence of a lot of high and new technology and the continual adjustment of war aims have provided enough space for the selection of dominant weapons and the combination of dominant weapons with other weapons, and have, at the same time, also made the dominant-subordinate relationship between dominant weapons and the other weapons even more complicated. The same factors are also affecting the use of the means of war. It is becoming obsolete to automatically consider military action the dominant means and the other means supporting means in war. Perhaps, in the not too distant future, the military means will be only one of all the available means in wars such as one of fighting terrorist organizations of the bin Laden category. A more effective means that can strike at bin Laden in a destructive way is perhaps not the cruise missile, but a financial suffocation war carried out on the Internet. As means have become more complicated, there has emerged a consequence that is unexpected to all soldiers: the civilianization of war. Therefore, here the issue of the relationship between the dominant force and all forces under discussion here also encompasses the issue of degree of participation of the entire population in war, in addition to the deployment, allocation, and use of military forces in combat operations. As professional soldiers’ war or quasi-war activities have increasingly become an important factor affecting national security, the issue as to which constitute the dominant force in future wars, an issue which has never been a question, has become a question worldwide. For example, the incidents of attacks conducted by “web rascals” on the network centers of the U.S. Defense Department and the Indian Defense Ministry were evidence in this regard. Whether an action is a pure war action, a non-war military action, or a nonmilitary war action, any action of a combat nature will entail an issue of how to accurately select the main direction of operation and the main point of attack, that is, to determine your main orientation in view of all the factors of the war concerned, the battlefields, and the battle fronts. This is the most difficult issue even for all those commanders who are in control of good weapons, a multitude of means, and sufficient manpower. However, Alexander, Hannibal, Nelson, and Nimitz as well as Sun Wu and Sun Bin of ancient China were good at selecting main directions of attack which would surprise enemy forces completely. Liddell Hart also noted this point. He referred to the approach of selecting the line of least resistance and the direction of action least expected by the enemy as the “indirect strategy.”

section: Chapter 6: The Rule of Victory: The Side-Principal Rule
text:
Through analysis, the trace of the rule of victory can be seen in every victory, whether achieved through surprise or non-surprise moves.  Victory is the effect of the side-principal principle demonstrated in either a “surprise” or “non-surprise” way.  Regardless of how clearly we state the side-principal rule, its application remains fuzzy. Sometimes, fuzziness is the best way to achieve overall clarity – an Eastern style of thinking that intersects with Occidental wisdom at the golden ratio of 0.618. This fusion of Occidental logic and precision with Eastern instinct and understanding has generated the rule of victory discussed here, combining Eastern mystery and Occidental rigor.

[Footnotes 1-23 provide historical and philosophical context, referencing Pythagoras, architectural principles, dive-bombing tactics, battles from Chinese and Western history (Arbela, Cannae, Trafalgar), World War II strategies (Manstein Plan, Pearl Harbor), the Fourth Middle East War, and modern military doctrines (comprehensive superiority, global engagement, system of systems). The footnotes also discuss the “surprise-non-surprise” principle from Sun Tzu’s Art of War.]

section: Chapter 7: Ten Thousand Methods Combined as One: Combinations that Transcend Boundaries
text: Modern warfare has far-reaching consequences, impacting everything from gasoline and food prices to the stock market and ecological balance, invading our homes through television screens. Understanding the rules of victory, as discussed in the previous chapter, doesn't guarantee it, just as knowing racing techniques doesn't guarantee winning a race.

section: Introduction to Unrestricted Warfare - Rules of Victory and the Modern Soldier
text: The rules of victory in war are not merely about battlefield tactics, but about a deeper understanding of the laws of warfare. Future wars will demand more than battlefield ingenuity; they will be fought and won beyond the traditional battlefield. This requires a complete rethink of military strategy, going beyond the limitations of traditional military thinking.  Modern military figures, even those seemingly contemporary, are not truly "modern" in this sense. A chasm has appeared between traditional and modern soldiers, demanding a leap in military thought. The necessary new method involves a Machiavellian approach – achieving objectives by any means necessary. This represents a break from traditional chivalry and embraces a more pragmatic, results-oriented approach to warfare.

“Going beyond limits” in warfare means transcending traditional boundaries – physical, spiritual, technical, or otherwise. This includes the boundaries between battlefield and non-battlefield, weapon and non-weapon, combatant and non-combatant, state and non-state. It involves breaking free from ideological constraints and selecting the most appropriate means, including extreme measures when necessary. In a technologically integrated era, there are abundant resources available to break through limitations, requiring a more thorough approach to transcending traditional ways of thinking. Modern warfare demands combining all available resources, both material and non-material, and employing them according to the rules of victory. This requires a skilled hand, a concept of “going beyond limits,” surpassing boundaries while conforming to the laws of victory. This leads to a new method of warfare: “modified combined war that goes beyond limits.”

“Going beyond limits” does not mean the absence of limits, but rather the expansion of them. It involves going beyond the intrinsic boundaries of a specific area or direction, combining opportunities and means from various areas to achieve objectives. This includes “supra-national combinations” – combining national, international, and non-state organizations. The nation-state is no longer the sole focus of security; modern countries are increasingly influenced by regional and global organizations, multinational corporations, NGOs, and other non-state actors. This signals a shift from great power politics to supra-national politics. While big powers still play a dominant role, far-sighted nations are leveraging supra-national entities to expand their influence. The example of the Euro unifying the European Community highlights this trend.  The era of state-vs-state conflicts is fading, giving way to an era where problems are resolved through supra-national means on a larger stage.

section: The US and Supra-National Combinations: The Case of Iraq
text: In a world of interconnected influences, achieving security and pursuing interests solely through national means is difficult.  Saddam Hussein’s attempt at territorial occupation proved outdated and ineffective.  The United States, in contrast, has historically pursued its interests through supra-national means, gathering allies and avoiding isolated action. In the Gulf War, the US utilized a typical supra-national combination, collaborating with other nations, maneuvering political groups, and securing UN support for intervention and subsequent sanctions against Iraq. This demonstrates the growing trend of supra-national combinations in warfare and conflict resolution. This trend is further fueled by global economic integration, internationalized domestic politics, networked information, rapid technological advancements, concealed cultural conflicts, and the strengthening of non-state organizations.  These factors drive nations, both large and small, to adopt supra-national combinations for problem-solving. Consequently, threats to modern nations often originate from supra-national powers rather than individual countries, making supra-national combinations a crucial countermeasure.

section: Historical Precedents and Modern Adaptations of Supra-National Combinations
text: Supra-national combinations are not a new concept; they have been employed since ancient times, as seen in the Spring and Autumn period, the Warring States period, and the Peloponnesian War.  However, modern applications differ significantly from ancient practices.  While ancient combinations involved state-to-state alliances, modern versions utilize vertical, horizontal, and interlocking combinations of state, supra-national, transnational, and non-state actors. Schwarzkopf’s Gulf War strategy exemplifies a modern adaptation of the classic “alliance + combined forces” model. This “state + supra-national + transnational + non-state” model revolutionizes warfare, altering its fundamental nature.  Resolving conflicts or conducting warfare through this combination represents the essence of supra-national combinations.

Supra-national combinations will be a country’s most powerful weapon in attempting to accomplish national security objectives and secure strategic interests…The key to the issues which we want to discuss here certainly does not lie in whether or not the Americans have intentionally used such a weapon. But as a super-weapon, is it practical? The answer is affirmative.

“Domain” is a concept derived from the concept of territory and used to delineate the scope of human activities…Faced with the far-reaching influence of military and nonmilitary conflicts in every corner of the world, only if we break through the various kinds of boundaries in the models of our line of thought, take the various domains which are so completely affected by warfare and turn them into playing cards deftly shuffled in our skilled hands, and thus use beyond-limits strategy and tactics to combine all the resources of war, can there be the possibility that we will be confident of victory.

During a war between two countries, during the fighting and killing by two armies, is it necessary to use special means to wage psychological war aimed at soldiers’ families far back in the rear area?…means of unequal size are like a set of Chinese boxes one inside the other

A means at one level serves a higher objective, while at the same time being the objective for the means at the next lower level.  The complexity of what a means is still remains. We can examine any object from any angle or level and understand what a means is.  From the perspective of domains, the military, politics, diplomacy, economics, culture, religion, psychology, and the media can often be seen as means.  Domains can be subdivided. For example, in the military domain, strategy and tactics, military deterrence, military alliances, military exercises, arms control, weapons embargoes, armed blockades, right down to the use of force, these are all military means. Economic assistance, trade sanctions, diplomatic mediation, cultural infiltration, media propaganda, formulating and applying international rules, using United Nations resolutions, etc., belong to different domains such as politics, economics, or diplomacy, but are increasingly used as standard military means by statesmen.

From the perspective of methods, philosophical methods, technical methods, mathematical methods, scientific methods, and artistic methods can all be used as means in war.  Technology, for instance, with the development of information technology, materials technology, space technology, bioengineering technology, and other new technologies, expands the array of means.  Mathematics influences military terminology: disposition of forces, base figures of ammunition, calculation of trajectories, probabilities of deaths and woundings, combat radii, and explosive yields. Philosophical, scientific, and artistic methods support military wisdom and action, hence the terms military philosophy, military science, and military art.

Liddell Hart defined strategy as “the art of using military means to achieve political objectives.”  The concept of means is broad and multi-layered.  Only by expanding our understanding of means, and grasping the principle that there is nothing which cannot be considered a means, can we avoid being overwhelmed when employing them.

During the 1978 Iran hostage crisis, the United States initially considered rash military action. After these failed, it shifted tactics, freezing Iranian assets, imposing an arms embargo, supporting Iraq in its war with Iran, and adding diplomatic negotiations. The crisis ended when all these channels were used together. In a complex world, the form and application of means are constantly changing, and a single means, however effective, is less advantageous than several means used in combination. Supra-means combinations are becoming extremely necessary, yet few countries are aware of this. Non-state organizations, however, are actively pursuing the combined use of means. For example, the Russian Mafia combines assassination, kidnapping, and hacker attacks; terrorist organizations combine bombs, hostage-taking, and network raids; and speculators combine currency, stock, and futures market manipulation with public opinion manipulation to wage financial wars.

These combined means, while often violent, are not inherently military.  Their combined use offers insights into effective military and non-military means in war. The effectiveness of a means is not determined by its category or moral standing, but by whether it is the best way to achieve the objective.  Supra-means combinations surpass not other means, but the moral standards or normal principles intrinsic to the means themselves.  This is more difficult and complex than simply combining means. We can only achieve true freedom in choosing means—the beyond-limits realm—if we complete our understanding of the beyond-limits concept. We need to find the optimum way to combine different means and create new means to achieve objectives.

In this era of economic integration, a powerful country attacking another’s economy and defenses cannot rely solely on economic blockades, trade sanctions, military threats, or arms embargoes.  It must adjust its financial strategy, using currency revaluation or devaluation, combined with manipulating public opinion and changing rules to create financial turbulence and economic crisis in the targeted country, weakening its overall power, including its military strength. The Southeast Asian financial crisis, while not intentionally caused by a major power manipulating currency, demonstrates this possibility. Even a quasi-world power like China can jolt the world economy by changing its economic policies. If China had devalued the Renminbi in 1998, it would have worsened the Asian economies and caused a cataclysm in global capital markets, harming even the United States. Such an outcome would be more effective than a military strike.  Information exchange and intertwined interests are broadening the meaning of warfare. Any decisive country has various capabilities to threaten others beyond military means.  The use of single means is becoming less effective, while the advantages of combined means are becoming more evident. This opens the door for supra-means combinations in warfare and quasi-war actions.

When a war becomes history, its course emerges gradually, from small-scale local fights to interconnected campaigns and potentially spreading to intercontinental or global war.  Each level is marked by casualties, victories, defeats, and strategies.  The entire process is an accumulation of outcomes.  We aim to evade the rule of gradual escalation by finding a way to continuously create the decisive moment, rather than waiting for it through accumulation, and establishing this as a strategy.

Our goal is to break down the stages of war and reassemble them at will.  For example, combining a tactical action directly with a strategic action or an action at the level of wars.  We envision warfare like a dragon with interchangeable limbs, torso, and head, freely assembled and maneuverable. This is the method of "supra-tier combinations."

A level is a restriction, similar to national boundaries or limitations on means, which must be surpassed in supra-combination warfare. Herman Kahn's stages of nuclear war, while applicable to other forms of warfare, are too finely delineated and focus on intensity rather than the essential nature of war's levels. We propose dividing the levels of war based on scale and corresponding methods, simplifying to four levels:

*   **Grand War-War Policy:** Supra-national to national level military and non-military actions. The corresponding function is "war policy" or "grand strategy," focusing on political stratagems for warfare.
*   **War-Strategy:** National level military actions, including non-military actions. The corresponding function is "strategy," a country's military or war stratagems.
*   **Campaigns-Operational Art:** Combat actions below war but above battles.  The corresponding function, lacking a title and often conflated with "campaigning," is termed "operational art," positioned between strategy and tactics.
*   **Battles-Tactics:** Basic scale combat actions. The corresponding function is "tactics."

Traditional military training focuses on mastering these functions at each level.  However, future soldiers must learn to disrupt these levels, combining factors from supra-national actions to specific battles to win wars.  Supra-tier combinations involve interchangeable roles for war policy, strategy, operational art, and tactics, such as using a strategic non-military method for a tactical mission, or a tactical method for a war policy objective.  The trend of warfare increasingly shows that problems at one level are not solely solvable by means at that level.  Regardless of resource allocation, combining levels and methods is key.

…it is a feasible method so long as it works well. Bin Laden used a tactical level method of only two truckloads of explosives and threatened U.S. national interests on the strategic level, whereas the Americans can only achieve the strategic objective of protecting their own safety by carrying out tactical level retaliation against him. Another example is that in past wars, the smallest combat element was the combination of a man and a machine, and its usefulness would normally not go beyond the scale of battles. In beyond-limits war, by contrast, the man-machine combination performs multiple offensive functions which span the levels from battles to war policy. One hacker + one modem causes an enemy damage and losses almost equal to those of a war. Because it has the breadth and secrecy of trans-level combat, this method of individual combat very easily achieves results on the strategic and even war policy levels. This is the gist and significance of supra-level combinations. In warfare and non-military warfare which is primarily national and supra-national, there is no territory which cannot be surpassed; there is no means which cannot be used in the war; and there is no territory and method which cannot be used in combination. The applicability of the actions of war to the trend of globalization is manifested in the word “beyond.” This word is sufficient to mean using one to apply to ten thousand, but what we mean by ten thousand methods combined as one is precisely covered by the word “beyond.” It must be pointed out once again that combined war that goes beyond limits is first of all a way of thinking, and only afterwards is it a method.

Principles are a code of conduct, but not an absolute one. In the history of warfare, the first person credited with using principles to regularize methods of fighting should be Sun Tzu. Principles which he advocated, such as “know the enemy and yourself and in a hundred battles you will never be defeated,” “strike where the enemy is not prepared, take him by surprise,” and “avoid the solid and strike the weak,” are still articles of faith for modern strategists. But in the West, 2,400 years later, Napoleon would reveal his real desire to the world famous Saint-Cyr Military Academy…: “To write a book, describing the principles of war precisely, and provide it to all soldiers.” Unfortunately, when he fought and won wars he had no time to write, and after he was defeated he was no longer in the mood. To a marshal who created nearly 100 victories in his lifetime, this should be neither too big nor too little a regret. But having been born a great man, it was enough for him to leave behind a brilliant record of victories for posterity to scour in search of his path to victory. A hundred years afterwards, from the wars directed by this old enemy who elicited dread from British people both during life and after death, a British general by the name of J. F. C. Fuller induced five principles for directing modern wars. All of the West’s principles of modern warfare are descended from these. Although later military regulations of quite a few countries and several military theorists proposed this or that as a principle of war, all of those things differ only in minor ways with those originated by Fuller. This is because, from the beginning of the Napoleonic wars to the time prior to the Gulf War, apart from the continual increase in lethality and destructiveness, there was no reason for an essential change in the nature of war itself. Now the situation has changed, because of all that happened during and after the Gulf War. The introduction of precision guided weapons, non-lethal weapons, and non-military weapons has derailed warfare from its mad dash down the track toward increased lethality and destructiveness. Events have set in motion the first change of course since the dawn of history. This has laid a new track for war in the next century, and given rise to principles with which professional military people are unfamiliar. No principle can rest on a flimsy platform waiting to collapse. This is even more true of principles of war. Regardless of which military thinker produced them, or whatever military headquarters “regulations they come from, the principles are all undoubtedly the product of repeated tempering in the furnace and on the anvil of war. If there had been no wars in the Spring and Autumn period there would be no principles of Sun Tzu. If there had been no Napoleonic wars, there would be no principles of Fuller.
